bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to the Editor of World's Work, April 10, 1924

div1.p: Kean writes to the editor in order to dispute the claims made by Marie Gorgas in her article on her husband. He requests that a letter of clarification be published in the journal.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to the Editor of World's Work, April 10, 1924
div1.opener:
JRK/FM
10 April 1924.
Editor,
World's Work,
Doubleday, Page & Co.,
Garden City, N.Y.
Dear Mr. Editor:
div1.p:
Shortly after the appearance of the April number of the World's
Work I received a letter from Mrs. Walter Reed who was in great distress
on account of certain statements made in the article published in that
number by Mrs. Gorgas and Mr. Hendrick entitled “Yellow Fever Meets Its
Master”. Mrs. Reed appealed to me for a correction of these statements
because I am an old friend who was intimately associated with Major Walter
Reed during his work in Cuba, having been Chief Surgeon of the Department
of Western Cuba on the staff of General Fitzhugh Lee, to whose headquarters
Major Reed was attached during the work of his commission in Cuba. General
Leonard Wood placed in my hands for disbursement the money which he allott-
ed from the Cuban revenue for the necessary expenditures of the board.
I state these facts to you to show that I am a competent witness in this
matter.

I have sent the inclosed letter to the Surgeon General of the
Army, Major General M. W. Ireland, who has this morning returned it to
me with his approval and with the suggestion that I ask you to publish
it. You will agree, I think, that it has been written not in any spirit
of hostile criticism but simply in justice to that splendid man, Walter
Reed, whose untimely death prevented him from receiving the honors and
rewards which his scientific work with regard to typhoid fever and yellow
fever merited.

I hope that you may be able to publish this letter in the next
issue. If you are not willing to publish it, please return it to me in
order that I may send it to the Surgeon General for publication elsewhere.
div1.closer:
Yours very truly, J. R. Kean,
Colonel, Medical Corps, U.S. Army. Incl.
Mr Burton J. Hendrick is with Doubleday
Page & Co Publishers of the World's Work
